comments:
Many times lately, I have been getting an AssertionFailedException from JDT when
opening a *.java file in the editor. The editor view is mostly blank, but
contains a stop-sign icon and a message: "Unable to create this part due to an
internal error. Reason for the failure: Assertion failed:"

Notice that there is no message after the colon in this string. I can hit a
"details" button in the view and see the stack trace from the exception. It's
pasted below.

If I exit the workbench, reopen it on the same workspace, and try again, it
usually succeeds in opening the view.

I am using the final Eclipse 3.1 build, with JDT inside. (Not 3.1.1, or a
development build, or anything more recent than the 3.1 final build.) Maybe this
is fixed in 3.1.1; I couldn't say. It's not reproducible, but it's frequent
enough to be irritating. 

Once this happens in a particular session, it always happens from then on when
opening the same file. Other files can be opened successfully during that session.

Here is the stack trace:

What VM are you using? Looking at the code this cannot happen unless there's a
(JIT) bug in the VM.

Either upgarde the VM or try to run with disabled JIT if you cannot switch to
another VM.

Sorry, I had meant to say in the initial description: I am using the IBM JVM 
version 1.4.2 with the -Xj9 option - that is, specifying the "J9" JVM instead 
of the "classic" (a.k.a "Sovereign") version of the IBM JVM.

I believe you're right that a JVM quirk is involved: in the past when I have 
chosen a different JVM, I don't think I've ever seen this. It would be helpful 
for IBM if you could describe the circumstances around this assertion and why 
it "can't happen," so I can talk to the JVM people about it. Feel free to use 
private e-mail. Thanks.

I now see that this is a duplicate of bug 55814 ... I checked my IBM J9 JVM
version and it is quite old: the JIT was built in January 2004. According to bug
55814 this problem was fixed around May of 2004. I'll get a newer JVM and see if
the problem ever comes up again.
